bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: awa kisêyiniw êkwah ôsisima oskinîkiwa , nîsiwak pikoh wîkiwâhk . This old man and his grandson, a youth, dwelt, the two, alone, in a tipi.
êkwah kitimâkêyimêw awa kisêyiniw ôsisima . The old man was fond of his grandson.
mâcîw tahkih . He always hunted.

kêtahtawê ,
hâw , nôsisi , mahtih kit-ôtastotiniyin nika-kakwê-nipahâw , itêw ôsisima . Then at one time, “Now then, my grandchild, I think I shall try to kill some creature that you may use for a hat,” he said to his grandson.

êhag
itik . “Yes,” answered the other.
osâm awiyak ntastâhik , kit-ôtihtisk , itêw awa kisêyiniw ôsisima . “For too much does someone frighten me with the foreboding that he will come upon you,” said the old man to his grandson.
tâpwê nipahêw mistâposwa ; êkwah pahkonêw . And so he killed a jack-rabbit; then he skinned it.
hâw , nôsisi , nika-kakwê-nipahâw kotak , kit-ôtastotiniyin , itêw ôsisima . “Now then, my grandchild, I shall try to kill some creature, that you may have another hat,” he told his grandson.
êhag , itik . “Yes,” answered he.
êkwah kâhkâkiwa nipahêw ; pahkonêw . Then he killed a raven; he skinned it.

hâw , nôsisi , ôma kâ-mâciyân tahto-kîsikâw , awiyak otihtiskih , êkâ wiya kitâpamâhkan , itik omosôma . “Now, my grandchild, when I hunt each day, should anyone come to you, do not look at him,” his grandfather told him.

nimosô , itêw ,
mahtih kakwê-nipah paspaskiw ; nik-ôwahpihtisin , itêw . “Grandfather,” he told him, “Please try to kill a partridge; let me have a tobacco-pouch of it,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Indeed, my grandchild, what you say is right.
I will help you.

p.seg: êkotah asiwahâhkan awa asiniy , pêhpêkahâkan , itêw ôsisima . Put this stone inside, and you have a slung-shot club,” he told his grandson.
êkwah osîhtâw cacêkahkwâna awa kisêyiniw . Then the old man made a set of darts.
hâw , nôsisi , kakwê-naskwênamôhkan ôhi cacêkahkwâna , kit-âpacihtâyin , itik omosôma . “Now, my grandchild, try to seize these darts on the run, that you may use them,” his grandfather told him.
êhag , itêw . “Yes,” he said to him.
êkwah mahtih , nôsisê , ôtah apih , itik . “And now, grandchild, sit over here,” the other told him.
pôtâcik : pôti asiniy apiw . He blew forth his breath: there lay a stone. LB on {pôtâcik}: Doubtless {pôtâcikêw}: “he blew,” or {pôtâtik}: “the other blew on him.”
hâ , osâm kinêsôwihitin ; mâskôc ka-sâkôcihikon ! itik omosôma ; “Ho, I am leaving you too weak; perhaps something will overcome you!” his grandfather said to him;
mahtih , nôsisê , pimisini ; kwayask sâsakicisini , itik omosôma . “Do, grandchild, lie down; lie down flat on your back,” his grandfather told him.
pâh-pôtâcik : He blew forth his breath more than once:

misiwê ocêpihtah misiwê itamoyiwa , aspin mâna itâmâskîhk , êkwah ê-mamâhcikwahpitikot ocêpihkak ohci . on all sides roots clung fast, roots from way down under the ground, until he was firmly tied down by the roots. FIX: ?? animacy mismatch on ocêpihkak. HCW: -ak --> ah
nôsisi , ômisi kik-êsiyîhkâson , itik ; “My grandchild, this shall be your name,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “Pine-Root-Man will be your name.

p.seg: êkâ wiya kitâpamâhkan awiyak , itik omosôma ; Do not look at anyone,” his grandfather told him;

seg.gloss: “Try to take with you these darts.

p.seg: iskwâhtêmahokanihk êkotah niwîh-tahkopitên ôhi kâ-miyitân , awa mîna kâhpihcis , itik omosôma ; Here to the stick of the doorflap I shall tie these things which I give you, and also your tobacco-pouch,” his grandfather told him;

seg.gloss: “Do not look at anyone that may come to you.”

p.seg: êhag , nimosô , itêw . “Yes, grandfather,” he told him.
tâpwê namoya kêkway wîh-kitâpahtam iskwâhtêm . Accordingly not at all would he look at the door.
wêwêkisin ostikwânihk otakohpah . He lay wrapped up, with his blanket over his head.
kîtahtawê pê-sêwêpayiyiw kêkway . Then at one time something came a-jingling.
pêhtam ; wêwêkistikwânêw ; kontah kâ-pê-pâhpiwiht pêhtam . He heard it; he wrapped up his head; he heard someone come near to him, gaily laughing.
iskwêwak ôki , itêyihtam ; “These are women,” he thought,
êwakoni k-êtât nimosôm , itêyihtam . “These are the ones my grandfather meant,” he thought.
pôtih kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit . There, they came in.
hêy , ês âwa ât êh-na-nipât , êkâ kâ-wi-kitâpamikoyahk kîtimosinaw ! itik . “Hey, and so there he sleeps, just the same, our sweetheart who will not look at us!” they said to him.
kêhcinâ miyosiwak ! itêyihtam aw oskinîkiw . “Surely they must be beautiful!” thought the young man.
êkosi kâh-kitotik , nanêtohk êy-itokot ; nama wîh-kitotêw . Then they kept talking to him, saying all kinds of things; but he would not speak to them.
tâpwê kipakwâtikonaw kîtimosinaw watapîw-iyin ! itik ; “Truly, we are disdained by our sweetheart Pine-Root!” they said to him;
nyâ , kîwêtân , ntâyîm ! itwêyiwa . “Come, let us go home, sister-wife!” they said.
pôtih kâwi pê-paskwâpiyiwa pêyak , pêyak k-âti-pâhpiyit . Then, look you, one came back, peeping in, while the other went laughing on her way. ?? pasakwâpi VAI ‘shut eyes’? HCW: don't know
pôtih nk-êtâpin iskwâhtêmihk , êh-itêyihtahk ; “Just let me look at the doorway,” he thought;
misawâc nam âwiyak nka-wâpamâw , êy-itêyihtahk . “After all, I shall not see anyone,” he thought.
ncawâc pâskihkwêyiw , iyâyaw iskwâhtêmihk êy-itâpit . He uncovered his head, and eagerly looked at the doorway.

hêy , ât êcik âwa êkâ êh-nipât , êkâ kâ-wîh-kitâpamikoyâhk ! êh-itwêyit , k-âti-pâhpiyit . “Hey, and so he is not asleep after all, the one who will not look at us!” she said, and off she went, laughing.
pasikôpayiw ; kahkiyaw paspaskipayihtâw ôhi watapiyah . He leapt to his feet; he ripped through all those cedar-roots.

êh-pîcicipayit , ôhih kâ-kî-osîhtwâkot omosôma naskwênam ; pimiwitâw . As he dashed forth, he seized those things which his grandfather had made for him; he took them along. CHECK if kâ-kî-osîhtwâkot is relational. HCW: yes. Don't throw out the w.
pêyakwan iyikohk askôwêw . He did nothing but follow them.

kahkiyaw tahkonam ôhih kâ-kî-osîhtowâht kit-ôtastotinit , mîna wahpihtisah , mîna cikahkwânah . He held in his hand all the things that had been made for him to wear as headgear, and his tobacco-pouch, and the darts.
namwâc askiy nôkwaniyiw itêh ka-wiy-itohtâyit pêyak wîtimosah . no land was visible there whither one of his sweethearts was headed.
hêy hêy ! âskaw ôma wa-wîhtamâkêwak . “Hey, hey!” they would shout now and then, as a sign.
tânisi êsiyîhkâsoyin , nîtimosê watapîw-iyin ? itik . “What is your name, sweetheart, Pine-Root?” one asked him.

seg.q: ha ! namoya niyi nîkân ta-kî-wîhtamâtakok niwîhôwin !
seg.gloss: “Ho! I will not be the first to tell you my name!

p.seg: kiyawâw nîkân ta-wîhtamawiyêk kiwîhôwiniwâwa ! itêw wîtimosah . First you must tell me your names!” he told his sweetheart.
êhag ! ntâyîm , kiya nîkân wîhtamaw kîtimosinaw kiwîhôwin , itêw osîma . “So be it! My sister-wife, do you first tell our sweetheart your name,” she told her younger sister.

seg.q:
êhag , nêma iskoh kâ-nêyâk , êkotê iskoh ,
k-ôskâcihko-mispohk , ntisiyîhkâson .
seg.gloss: “Yes. As far as yon point of the land, up to yonder place, ‘Rain-of-Awls’ is my name.

p.seg: hâ , niyâk ! itêw . “There, be off!” she said to the others.
êkwah sôskwâyiw , ê-miskwamîwiyik . Then it was slippery on the ice.
otinam ocikahkwân ; saskawohtêw . He took one of his darts; he leaned on it as he walked.
kotak otinam ; pêhpêkahâkan êkotah kikamohtâw . He took another; he attached the slung-shot club to it.
êh-misêkaniyik pimohtêw . He waled across the expanse of ice.
âtah oskâcihkwa êh-pahkihtihkih ostikwânihk , âhci pikoh pa-pmohtêw . Though awls were falling on his head, nevertheless he kept walking on.
wêtihtahkik ôma kâ-nêyâyik , pôti êyâpic pê-wîcêwêwak wîtimosiwâwa . When they had reached that promontory, there, again they came and kept their sweetheart company.

seg.gloss: “Hey, but surely we had our fun of him, my sister-wife!
But now it is his turn to name himself!”

seg.q: hâ , namôya ! kiyawâw nîkân kika-wîhtamawinâwâw kiwîhyôwiniwâw .
seg.gloss: “Ho, no! You first are to tell me your names.”

p.seg:
êhag ! nêmay isko kâ-nêyâk , êkotah iskoh
kâ-sôskwâstimêwi-pimohtêw , ntisiyîhkâson , itik . “Very well! As far as yon point of the land, up to yonder place, ‘Walks-Blown-on-the-Ice,’ is my name,” she told him.
êkwah tâ-sôskwâsit . And then the wind was to carry him along on the smooth surface.
sâkahikan tâwakâm namoya kaskatin , êkotê kit-êtâsit awa oskinîkiw . The lake was not frozen shut in the middle, and thither the youth was to be borne by the wind.
êkwah êh-ati-sipwêhtêcik , msi-yôtiniyiw . Then, when they set out on their way, there came a great wind.
cikahkwânah otinam aw ôskinîkiw ; êkwah saskahohtêw . The youth took a lance; he used it as a cane.
êh-âta-yôtiniyik , pa-pmohtêw . In spite of the wind, he kept walking.
piyisk otihtamwak . At last they reached the place.

seg.gloss: “There!”

seg.q: hêy , âhci pikoh kiwîcêkonaw awa kîtimosinaw !
seg.gloss: “Hey, in spite of all, our sweetheart is keeping us company!
But now it is his turn to name himself.”
“Yes, sweethearts.

seg.q:
nêma kisiwêk ôma kâ-nêyâk , êkotah iskoh ,
kâ-kisâkamitêwi-kimiwahk , nitisiyîhkâson , animah iskoh kâ-nêyâk .
seg.gloss: “As far as yon close-by point of the land, up to yonder place, ‘Hot-Water-Rain’ is my name, as far as yon point of the land.
“But now, sweetheart, be off; we will follow you.”

p.seg: mayaw ê-sipwêhtêt , âsay mâcih-kimiwaniyiw . As soon as he started off, at once it began to rain.
tâpiskôc êh-ohtêk nipiy , êkos îsi kisâkamitêyiw . Like boiling water, so hot was the liquid.

êkwah ôki ,
hêy , nikîsison ! pikwîtah êy-ayinisocik ok îskwêwak , kêtisk êy-otihtahkik . Then those women, “Hey, I am being scalded!” and they dodged hither and thither, and only with difficulty reached the goal.

pôtih ,
hêy , tâpwê kîtimosinaw âyimaniyiw owîhôwin ! There, “Hey, truly a dangerous thing is our sweetheart's name!

seg.gloss: Once more let him name himself.”
“Yes, indeed!”
“But now our little wooden houses are in sight.”

seg.q:
hâ , nîtimosê , nêm îsko wâskâhikan kâ-nôkwahk , êkotah ,
kâ-nânâhtêwi-pimohtêw k-âsê-mohkitohtêw , nitisiyîhkâson .
seg.gloss: “Why, sweetheart mine, as far as yon house that we see, up to that place [no translation] is my name.”

p.seg: êkwah ôk iskwêwak ôtah oskotâkâwâwa omis îsiwêpinamwak ôtêh ; [no translation] HCW: then the women flung their skirts over here like this.
êkwah asêhtêwak , tâpiskôc ômisi êh-nawakîcik . then they walked backwards, stooping over just like this.

seg.q: hêy , tânisi mâka mîna ôki piyêy-isinâkosicik kîs-kîskwêhkâniskwêwak ?
seg.gloss: “Hey, what is the matter now with these little ones that make themselves look like prairie chickens?”
“Hey, mother, do not speak!
Before you know it, you will be speaking your son-in-law's name!

seg.q: ôwîhôwin ôma kâ-tôtamâhk , isko kiwâskâhikanihk tâwikiskamâhko !
seg.gloss: It is his name, what we are doing until we bump into your house!”

p.seg: pikonitah awâsisah kâ-pêhtâkosiyit . Then, from no one knew where, was heard the cry of a child. LB: This is probably the same laconically stated supernatural symbol of the conquest as in Jones' _Fox Texts_ 196, 13.
êy-asêhtêcik , êh-asê-môhkitohtêcik , tâwikisinwak owâskâhikanisiwâhk . Walking backwards [no translation] they landed against their little wooden house.
êkwah pôyôwak . Then they stopped.

seg.q: hâêy , nitawâsimisitik , êkotê anah ohtapik , onipêwinik ;
seg.gloss: “Hey, my children, sit over there with that man, make your bed over there;

p.seg: osâm nikîskwêhkwasiskin ; nika-pa-pistiskâkân ninahâhkim , itwêw . I am too much given to sleep-walking; I might run into my son-in-law,” she said.
kawisimôwak , êh-tipiskâyik . When darkness fell, they went to bed.
kêkâc êh-wâpaniyik , hêy , kîtahtawê kâ-papâmitâcimot awa nôtokêsiw ; mistahi kîskwêhkwasiw ! When it was almost daybreak, hey, there was the old woman crawling about; a bad case of sleep-walking!
piyisk onahâhkisîma kospiwêpinik . At last her son-in-law shoved her aside.

hêy , ntawâsimisitik , ôma kâ-sâkahikaniwik , êkota ana kâ-misikitit amisk ostikwân êh-mîciyân êkwah osoy , itwêw awa nôtokêsiw ,
êkoyikohk iskah kâ-pôni-kîskwêhkwasiyân , wâpahki iskah êh-nipahât nnahâhkim , itwêw . “Hey, my children, that lake over there, if I ate the head and the tail of the giant beaver that is there,” said that old woman, “then, my dream tells me, I should cease to walk in my sleep, if tomorrow my son-in-law would kill it,” she said.
â , pêhtam awa ôskinîkiw . The youth heard that.
kîtahtawê êh-wâpaniyik , kîksêpâ sipwêhtêw , cîkahikan êh-otinahk êkwah ocikâhkwâna . Presently, when day broke, early in the morning he set out, taking an ax and his darts.
wêtihtahk sâkahikan , tâwakâm twâhipêw . When he reached the lake, in the centre he made a hole in the ice.
mistahi twâhipêw . He made a great hole in the ice.

êkwah ,
hâw , nimosô , pê-wayawî ! Then, “Now, O my grandfather, come forth!
kipêy-asamitin ôma ka-wîhkistaman ! itwêw . I have come to feed you that whose taste you so love!” he said.
kêtahtawê ka-pê-tâwatiyit ê-misikitiyit amiskwah . Presently, there came with gaping mouth the giant beaver.
cikahkwâtêw ; nipahêw . He threw his dart at it; he killed it.
ostikwân otinam , osoyiw mîna ; kîwêhtatâw . He took its head and its tail; he took them home.
pîhtokêwêpinam . He flung them into the house.

seg.gloss: “Here are the things your mother wants to eat!”

p.seg:
mâtôw awa nôtokêsiw ,
nipawâkan ! êh-itwêt ; The old woman wept, crying, “My dream guardian!”

seg.gloss: “Hey, as it is destined, go feed them to mortal men!

seg.q: ôhi ta-mîciwak ; anihi minah kâ-nipahimiht ta-nâtêwak ; ta-môwêwak !
seg.gloss: These things they will eat; and him who has been slain they will fetch; they will eat him!”

p.seg: tipiskâyiw âsay mina ; kawisimôwak . Again night fell; they went to bed.
êkosi âsay mina kîskwêhkwasiw awa nôtokêsiw . Then again that old woman walked in her sleep.

pôtih êh-pêkopayit ,
iskah ninahâhkim ê-nipahât okwâskwêpayihôsa ê-misikitiyit , êwakoni ê-nipahât nnahâhkisîm , êkoyikohk iskoh kâ-pôni-kîskwêhkwasiyân , ê-mîciyân ostikwân , itwêw . There, when she awoke, “By my dream, if my son-in-law kills the giant jumping-deer, if my son-in-law kills him, that will be the end of my sleep-walking, if I eat its head,” she said.

tâpwê kîkisêpâ kontah kâ-pêhtâkwaniyik ,
êwakwâ ! êh-itwêyit ayîsiyiniwah . Then really, in the morning, “There he goes!” the people's cry was heard.
ê-wayawî-kwâskohtit , pôt ôhi kî-pimi-kwâskwêkociniyiwa ôhi apsi-môsosah . When he leaped out of the house, lo, that jumping-moose had bounded past.
cikahkwâtêw ; nipahêw ; ostikwân pikoh otinam . He threw a dart at it; he killed it; he took only its head.
pîhtokêwêpinam . He flung it into the house.
êwakô anih kâ-wîh-mîcit kikâwiyiwâw ! itêw . “Here is what your mother wants to eat!” he called to them.
âsay mina mâtôw awa nôtokêsiw . Again the old woman wept.
nipawâkan êh-mihtâtak , ê-nipahiht ! itwêw ; “It is mourning my dream-spirit I am, that has been killed!” she said;

seg.gloss: “So now, my children, go feed it to mortal men!”

p.seg: âhag , itwêyiwa . “Yes,” they said.
êkwah môwêwak kotakak ayîsiyiniwak . Then the other people ate it.
êkwah tipiskâyiw . Then night fell.
âsay mina kîskwêhkwasiw awa nôtokêsiw . Again the old woman walked in her sleep.

hêy , ntawâsimisitik , ôtah ê-pimipayit wâwâskêsiw , êyakoni iskah ninahâhkisîm êh-nipahât , ostikwân iskah êh-mîciyân , êkoyikohk kâ-pôni-kîskwêhkwasiyân , itwêw . “Hey, my children, the elk that runs by here, I dreamt that if my son-in-law kills it, and I eat its head, then I shall cease to walk in my sleep,” she said.

kîkisêpâ kâ-pêhtahk ,
hah , namoya êkwah nka-nipahâw ! itêyihtam awa watapîw-iyin . In the morning, when he heard this, “Oh, I shall not kill him now!” thought that Pine-Root-Man.
êwakwâ wâwâskêsiw mâmaskâc ê-misikitit ! k-êtwêwiht , wayawîw . “There goes that elk that is so strangely large!” he heard the people cry, and went outside.
pêyak pikoh ocikâhkwân otinam . He took only one dart.
cikâhkwâtêw , êh-pimipahtâyit , watayihk aspin ocikâhkwân êh-kikiskamiyit . He threw the dart at it, as it ran past, and off it went with his dart in its belly.
kîwêw aw ôskinîkiw . The youth went back.
kahkiyaw otinam ocikâhkwânah , otastotinah . He took all his lances and his head-dresses.
pimitisahwêw . He pursued it.
pôtih êsa mâna itah êh-apiyit . There, he kept coming to where it had stopped to rest.
piyisk mitony otâkosiniyiw . At last it was late in the afternoon.
kâh-kîpa nahapiyiwa . At frequent intervals it was stopping to rest.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk êh-miywasiniyik sakâw . Presently he came to a pleasant grove of trees.
wâsakâm nîpisiyah ayâyiwah . Willows stood round about.
êkwah ati-misponiyiw . It was beginning to snow.

seg.gloss: “Oh, in any case, it will die not far away.
I shall sleep here.

p.seg: nika-pôh-pônên ; nika-kotawân , êh-itêyihtahk . I shall keep up a fire; I shall have a fire,” he thought.
mistahi sakâyiw , pisisik oski-mêtosah êkotôwahk , êkwah kayâsi-mistikwah , mâyi-mêtosah êkotôwank . It was a big grove, all of young poplars, and of old trees, of black-poplars.
êkwah pânaham , ê-kotawêt . then he cleared away the snow and made a fire.
ati-tipiskâyiw . It was getting dark.

kisiwâk ôtah êh-cimasôwit ,
mihtih , mêtosi-mihtih , ôma nika-pônên , êy-itêyihtahk , otinam . As a tree stood close by there, “Firewood, a log of poplar wood I shall put on my fire,” he thought, and started to take it.

ômis êh-tôtahk ,
hââ ! k-êtwêyit ôhi mistikwa . As he did so, “Oh, oh!” cried that tree.
pônihêw . He left it alone.
ncawâc akâmihk , akâmiskotêw anâskêw nîpisiyah maskosiyah mîna . He thought it better at the other side; at the other side of the fire he made his resting place of willow-boughs and grass.
nama wîh-nipâw . He could not sleep.
mistahi yôtiniyiw , êkwah êh-misponiyik . There was a strong wind, and it snowed.
kîtahtawê ôtêh nâmawan kîkway kâ-pêhtahk aw ôskinîkiw . Presently, there to the windward, the youth heard something.
kêtahtawê êh-itâpit , kâ-pê-pâh-pahkisiniyit . When he looked in that direction, there came someone falling.
otâsiyiwa ôtê asastêyiwa ; namwâc tahkopitamiyiwa . Her leggings were gathered down here; she had not tied them up at all.

seg.gloss: “Oh dear, oh dear! Grandmother! My poor grandmother will freeze to death!

seg.q: hâhâw , hâ , nôhko , êkotêh anih apih .
seg.gloss: Come, come, grandmother, sit over there.
I was chasing an elk which I had wounded and am tired from tramping through the deep snow.
Tomorrow I shall go kill it, grandmother.
We shall have meat to eat.”
“Alas, my dear grandchild, I am terribly starved;

seg.q: ôtêh kâ-wîkihk , êkotê êy-ispicihk , aspin kâ-wêpinikawiyân , êh-wanisiniyân .
seg.gloss: when they moved camp to where the people are staying, they went off leaving me behind, and now I have got lost.”

seg.q: â , tâpwê , nôhkô , ka-kîwêhtahitn ôtêh kâ-wîkihk , wâpahki , kê-nipahaki wâwâskêsiw .
seg.gloss: “Never mind, grandmother, I will take you back to where they live, tomorrow, as soon as I have killed the elk.
I will get some wood; you are too cold.”

p.seg: ah-iskonamawêw otâsiyiwa , mînah omaskisiniyiwa êh-tahkopitamwât . He pulled up her leggings for her and tied up her moccasins.
mistahi kitimâkêyinêw ôhkomah . He treated his grandmother very kindly.

seg.gloss: “Now, grandmother, I am going to sleep.

p.seg: kakwê-pônamâso , itêw ôhkomah . Try to keep up the fire to warm yourself,” he told his grandmother.
hêy , nôsisimis , kaskihtâyâni , nika-pônên , itik ôhkoma . “Alas, my dear grandchild, I if I am able, I shall put wood on the fire,” his grandmother answered him.

tâpwê nipâw aw ôskinîkiw , namoya ê-nipât , ê-wîh-wayêsihât ,
êwakôw awa nimanâcimâkan , êh-itêyihtahk . And so the youth went to sleep, but he did not really sleep, but only meant to deceive her, for the thought, “This is none other than my mother-in-law.”

kîtahtawê ,
nôsisê , nkawacin ! itik . Presently, “Grandchild, I am freezing!” she said to him.

âhci piko tâpiskôc êh-nipât ,
hhhrr ! êh-itwêt aw oskinîkiw . Unheeding, just as if he were asleep, “Hhhrr!” went the youth. LB on {hhhrr}: Deep breathing (not snoring) is imitated.

kîtahtawê awa nôtokêsiw kâ-waniskât ,
nêy ! mêtwêwanih nimistikom nka-takohâ ! k-êtwêyit . Presently that old woman rose from where she lay, and, “Yah, as it is destined, I shall add him to my trees!” she said.
êkwah ntohtawêw . He listened to her.
âpahamiyiwa ôtêh isi ; pôtih êh-kaskipitêyik maskihkiy . She took something from here, and it turned out to be some herbs tied in a packet. LB on {ôtêh}: Gesture to bosom-fold of garment.
nêy , namayêw ! âpisînikan êcik ôma ! itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . “Bah, this is not it! Why, this is the restorer!” said the old woman.
astâw . She put it down.

kotak ôtêh is âpahikêw , kotak êh-otinahk maskihkiy ,
nêê , êwako ! k-êtwêyit . From the same place she unfastened another, taking another medicine, and, “Yah, this is it!” she said.
êkwah mâ-mâkwahtam miscikos awa nôtokêsiw . Then the old woman chewed a little twig.
êkwah maskihkiy sâmihtitâw êkotah . Then she rubbed some of the medicine on it.
cêh , êyakw êcik ôma mistikwak k-ôh-osîhakik ! itwêw . “Faugh, and this is the stuff with which I make trees!” she said.
êkwah ôh ôsisima , omis îtisinam , ê-wîh-sâmahwât ôh ôskinîkiwa . Then she held it out at her grandson, meaning to touch the youth with it.
nawatinamwêw ospitoniyiw . He caught her by the arm.

seg.gloss: “Faugh, you filthy beast!”

p.seg: nawatinamiyiwa oma miscikos . He seized the stick she was holding.
êêê , nôsisê , cêskwah pitah ! âsay kisâkôcihin , itik ; “Hey, grandson, wait a moment! You have defeated me,” she said to him;

seg.q: hâ , nôsisê , cêskwah ayîsiyiniw ta-nihtawikihitôw nîkân ôtêh .
seg.gloss: “Now, grandson, in future time mortal man will live in successive generations.
They will gather crumbly wood.

seg.q: êkotah kit-ôh-kîsônak awâsis wîh-ôhpikicih , nîstah kit-ôhpikihak .
seg.gloss: There I shall keep warm the child that is to grow up, so that I too shall have part in bringing him up.
seg.note: LB on {awâsis}: Infants were (and sometimes still are) kept in the “moss-bag” which is filled with crumbly wood.

seg.gloss: But in the place of the setting sun I shall have my home.
‘I have dreamt of the old woman,’ when a mortal being speaks thus, he will speak truly.
So now, my grandson, touch me with it.”

p.seg: sâmahwêw ôhkomah ôm ohci maskihkiy . He touched his grandmother with that medicine.
pôt âwa mistik êh-kîskipayit kîh-nîpawiw . Lo, there stood a cleft tree.
êkosi mistikôw awa nôtokêsiw . Thus that old woman turned into a tree.

êkwah ôhih ,
â , kâ-kîh-itwêyit ,
ôma kotak maskihkiy âpisînikan , k-êtwêyit ôhkomah , êwako otinam . Then he took that of which his grandmother had said, “Oh, this other medicine is the restorer,” this he took.
sâmahwêw mistikwah . He touched a tree with it.
pôt ôhi kêhtêyiniwah kîh-nîpawiyiwa . Lo and behold, there stood an aged man.

hwhw ! itwêyiwa ;
nnêstokâpawin ! itwêyiwa . “Whew! he said; “I am weary of standing!” he said.
kisiwâk êh-cimasoyit mistikwah sâmahwêw . He touched with the stick a tree that stood close by.
kêkâc wâpaniyiw kotakah mîna . It was almost daybreak. Then another.
hâw , pôtih oskinîkiwa kîh-nîpawiyiwa . Then, behold, there stood a young man.

hâw , itêw ôhi kêhtêyiniwa ,
êkâya kihtimiyoh ; “Well now,” he said to the aged man, “do not be idle; LB on {kihtimiyoh}: Probably for {kihtimih}: “be lazy.”

seg.q: sâma ôhi ôki mistikwak ôm ôhci âpisînikan k-êtwêt nôhkom .
seg.gloss: touch these trees with this which my grandmother called the restorer.
seg.note: KR: LB may have misheard sâmahohk as sâma ôhi

seg.gloss: I shall go kill that elk.
I shall take ten men with me, so that they can bring all of it, for you to roast.

p.seg: pimâtisiyânih , kê-nîso-tipiskâkih nika-takohtân , itêw . If I live, after two nights I shall arrive,” he told him.
êhag , itik . “So be it,” the other answered him.
êkwah itohtêw . Then he went there.
ôhih wâwâskêsiwah nmoya wâhyaw nipiyiwa . The elk lay dead not far from there.
ostikwân otinam . He took the head.
kîwêhtatâw . He took it home with him.
hâ , wîkiwâhk takôhtatâw ; pîhtokêwêpinam . He brought it to their house, he threw it into the doorway.

seg.gloss: “Here is what your mother wanted to eat!”

p.seg: mâtôwak ôki oskinîkiskwêwak , ôkâwiyiwâwa ê-mawihkâtâcik . The young women were weeping, mourning for their mother.
kêhcinâhowak ê-sâkôcihimiht . They knew with certainty that she had been defeated.
êh-tipiskâyik , kawisimôwak . When darkness fell, they went to bed.
kospiwêpinêw wîtimosah awa watapîw-iyin . Pine-Root shoved his sweetheart aside.
êkosi êh-pêkopayit awa îskwêw , wîhtam . When thus the woman awoke, she told her dream.

hêyêy , kîtimosinaw awa iskah ôma wâskâhikanis kâ-pisikwastêyik , êkotah pêyakotipiskwah êh-ayât , êkoyihohk kâ-pôni-kîskwêhkwasiyân , itwêyiwa . “Hoho, I dreamt that if our sweetheart here stayed one night in that little wooden house that stands empty there, that would be the end of my sleep-walking,” she said.
nikohtêw , mistahi wâskâhikanisihk âh-pîhtokâtât ôhi mihtan . he gathered firewood, bringing a great many faggots into the little wooden house.
êh-tipiskâyik , êh-apit , nama kêkway iskwâhtêm . When night came, and he sat there, the doorway disappeared.
misiwêsiyiwa ôhi mistikwah . The wooden walls were unbroken.
mistahi ksiniyiw . It was very cold.
ay-awasôw . He warmed himself at the fire.
piyisk mêstihkasam omihtima . At last he had burned up all his firewood.
ntawâc kawisimôw . He needs went to bed.

kêtahtawê ,
hâw , ntastotin , kîsônin ! itêw mistah ê-misikitiyit wâposwah . Presently, “Come, my hat, warm me!” he said to the very large rabbit.
mitoni kiyîpa kawaciw awa wâpos . Very soon the rabbit was overcome by the cold.
otinêw ; pôh-pôtâtêw . He took him up; he kept breathing on him.

seg.gloss: “‘Warm me!’ I told you.”

p.seg: âsay mina kiyipa kawaciw . Again very quickly it was overcome by the cold. fix missing space (minakiyipa) in TEI file
âsay mina otinêw . Again he took it up.
êkwah kîtahtawê kawaciyiwa . Presently again it fell to the ground for cold.
namoy êkwah otinêw ; kotak otastotina otinêw . This time he did not take it up; he took his other hat.
hâw , nimosô , pawahokê ! itêw . “Come, my grandfather, beat out the walls of the house!” he told it.
êkwah awa kâhkâkiw kitôw , êh-pa-pakamahahk ôma waskahikan , misiwê êh-miskwamiwiyik . Then that raven croaked, as it beat the wooden house that was covered all over with ice.
kiyipa kawaciw awa kâhkâkiw . Quickly the raven was overcome by cold.
mâskôc nika-kawacin , itêyihtam awa oskinîkiw . “No doubt I shall freeze to death,” thought the youth.
êkwah ncawâc otinam ocikahkwân , êh-kawaciyit ôhi kâhkâkiwa . so now he needs took one of his darts, when that raven had succumbed to the cold.
otinam ocikahkwân , iskotêw êh-cikahkwâtahk . He took one of his darts, and threw it at the fire.
mistah iskotêwiyiw . There was a big fire.
mistahi kwâhkotêw ôma cikahkwân . That dart blazed high.
kiyipah âstawiw . Quickly the flame subsided.
kâhkâkiw awa pimisin , êh-kawacit . The raven lay there, overcome by cold.
êkwah kotak otinam ocikahkwân ; âsay mina cikahkwâtam ; âsay min êyôkô kwâhkotêw . Then he took another of his darts; again he threw his dart at it; this one, too, blazed up.
nimiskôtinêw kâhkâkiwah . He held the raven over the fire.
kêkâta wâpaniyiw . It was near dawn.
âsay mina âstawiw . Again the fire went out.
kotak otinam ; âsay mina cikahkwâtam iskotêw ; mistahi kwâhkotêyiw ocikahkwân . He took another; again he threw a dart at the fire; his dart made a great blaze.
kêtahtawê âstawiyiw . Presently it ceased to flame.
ê-wîh-âstawiyik , otinêw wâhpihcisah paspaskiwah ; êkwah pakamisimêw . When it was about to go out, he took his tobacco-pouch made of a partridge; he threw it down.
pawahokê , naphihc ! itêw . “Beat the walls of the house, my tobacco-pouch!” he said to it.
otinêw otastotinah . He took up his hat.
pôtâtêw ; pôtih pimâtisiyiwah kâhkâkiwah . He breathed on it; there, the raven was alive.
otinêw wâposwah ; pôtâtêw ; pôtih pimâtisiyiwa . He took up the rabbit; he breathed on it; lo, it lived.

êkwah ôhih paspaskiwah
pawahokê ! itêw . Then to the partridge he said, “Beat out the house!”

kîtahtawê awa paspaskiw sipwêpahtâw pîhcâyihk , ômis êh-tôtahk , ômis êh-itwêt :
nîpin ! nîpin ! nîpin ! Then soon that partridge set out, indoors there, doing like this, crying “Summer! Summer! Summer!” crying it incessantly;

pisisik êh-itwêt , êkwah kâhkâkiw pisisik êh-kitot , êkwah awa wâpos pikw îtah êh-kawipayihot . and at the same time the raven croaked without ceasing, and the rabbit threw itself down here, there, and everywhere.

nam êskwa êh-âstawiyik ocikahkwân ,
âyiwâkês kit-âtih-kwâhkotêw ôma nicikâhkwân ! Before his dart ceased to flame, “A while longer let this my dart blaze high!
nimosô nimêstinên ncikahkwânah ! itwêw . My grandfather, I have come to the end of my darts!” he said.
nêhih omosôma kâ-kitimâkêyimikot , êwakoni kây-itât . It was that far-off grandfather of his who had cared for him, whom he addressed.
êkwah kiyipa nama kêkway kônah pîhcâyihk ; Then, at once, there was no more snow within the house;
âyiwâkês kwâhkotêw . the fire blazed higher.

êkwah awa paspaskiw pîhcâyihk misiwê ispahtâw , êy-osihtât nîpin , nîpiyah êh-ntotamât , ôsisima êh-kanawêyimât . Then that partridge flew everywhere inside there, creating summer, calling for leaves, and serving its grandchild.
êkwah kêkâc êh-wâpahk , misiwê sâkikinwah nîpiyah ; Then when dawn was at hand, the leaves everywhere sprang forth;
mînah pîhcâyihk mohcihk mînisah ohpikinwah , otêhiminah . and inside there on the ground berries grew up, strawberries.

ayis awa paspaskiw namoya kipihtowêw , pisisik
nîpin ! êh-itwêt . For that partridge did not cease from its call, as all the time it cried, “Summer!”
êkwah awa nâpêw oskinîkiw kêtayôwinisêw ; Then that man, that youth, took off his clothes;
mosêskatêw ôtêh , êh-kîskwêpit . he was naked there, and sat reeling. LB: Or “sat playing”?
otinam mînisah , êh-mîcit . He took berries and ate them.
mitoni kisopwêyâw pîhcâyihk . It was very hot inside there.

êkwah êh-kîsikâk , âsay pîsim êh-nôkosit ,
hêy , ntâyîm , ntawih-wayawîwêpin kîtimosinaw ! [no translation]

seg.gloss: [no translation] (p.98)

p.seg: itohtêw pêyak . One of them went there.
êh-at-îtohtêt , ki-kitoyiwa kâhkâkiwa . As she came near, the raven called repeatedly. CHECK Is ki a reduplication? HCW: yes.
pêhtawêw ; mînah paspaskiwa . She heard it; also the partridge.
pôtih ê-paspâpit , kîh-mâ-môminêyiwa . There, when she peeped in, he was eating berries from the bush.

seg.q: hêy , nîtimosê , nama cî kah-kiy-asaminân ôhi kâ-mîciyan otêhimina ?
seg.gloss: “Hey, sweetheart, can you not give us some of those strawberries you are eating?”

seg.q: â , tipiskohk ê-nipâyân , kimis iskah êh-kitâyêk ôhih mînisah , êkoyikohk iskah kâ-pônih-kîskwêhkwasiyân tipiskohk .
seg.gloss: “Yes, last night when I slept, I dreamt that if you and your elder sister ate up all of these berries, then I should cease to walk in my sleep of nights.”

p.seg: nâ , êkâ m âyimahk ta-kitâhk , nîtimosê ! k-êtikot . “Why, surely it will not be difficult to eat them all, sweetheart!” was her answer to him.
kîwêw . She went back.

seg.gloss: “How now, my sister-fellow-wife, how now?”

seg.q: âpisîs anihi mînisah otêhiminah kitâyâhkoh , êkoyikohk ta-pônih-kîskwêhkwasit kîtimosinaw .
seg.gloss: “If we eat up the few berries, strawberries, there, then our sweetheart will cease to walk in his sleep.

p.seg: ê-ma-môminêt niwâpamâw , piko mâka ta-tôtamahk , ntâyîm , itêw . I saw him eating berries from the bush, and that is all we need to do, my sister-wife,” she told the other.
tohtêwak . They went there.

seg.gloss: “Come, my sweethearts, come in!
When you eat these up, then stop.
Then we shall get out of here.”

p.seg: mistahi miywêyihtamwak ôki kîskwêhkâniskwêwak . Those giddy wenches liked the idea.
êkwah môminêwak . So then they ate berries.
êyâtah-itêh-kâh-kitâtwâwi , êkotê pimipahtâw awah paspaskiw . Whenever they had in any place eaten them up, thither the partridge would run. CHECK Is this a changed conjunct, iyâtah-?
kâwih kikamoyiwa otêhiminah . The berries would be back on the stalk.
piyisk ôk îskwêwak ômisi itapiwak , osâm êh-kîspocik . At last those women sat like this, having overeaten.

seg.gloss: “Hey, sweetheart, you have defeated us!
Push us headlong to the direction of the noon.
You have defeated us.
We promise to be good.

seg.q:
ayîsiyiniwak ohpikitwâwi ,
nipawâtâw êh-kîskwêt iskwêw , itwêci , kita-tâpwêw .
seg.gloss: When mortal men come into being, if one shall say, ‘I have dreamt of a Giddy Woman,’ he will be telling the truth.
Come, sweetheart, be quick!”

p.seg: âh , isi-kîpipayihok ! itêw . “Well then, fling yourselves over!” he told them.

mayaw êh-kîpipayihocik , âsay kîh-atimwêwêtamwak , êh-âhtohtêcik ê-sâkôcihihcik mac-âyak . As soon as they had flung themselves over, at once they went noising it yon way, going to a new abode after their defeat, the evil beings.
êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of the sacred story.
